intro: Urvillea chacoensis, commonly known as the Chacoan urvillea, is a flowering plant native to the dry regions of South America, particularly in Paraguay and Argentina. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its woody stems and showy flowers. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, adapting to harsh conditions with deep root systems and thick leaves. Its flowers are usually pink or purple, and it produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small seeds.
